The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
Calumet has developed a comprehensive emergency response plan which is regularly used to train both in-house and local area responders. Calumet is prepared to handle a worst-case release by training its emergency responders in HAZWOPER Level 3, 40 CFR, Section 1910.120.

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
Calumet refining at Karns City, PA continually strives to improve its safety related systems. Its policies and procedures provide efficient means to minimize environmental impacts onsite and to the public. The facility restricts access to the Oleum storage tank to authorized personnel only, while surveillance cameras closely monitor operations for added security. Additionally, regular inspections, preventative maintenance, and internal and external audits of the system and safety mechanisms are conducted. A structured process is in place for the management team to review all potential process changes, including recommendations following process hazard analysis and compliance audits. These improvements, coupled with periodic reviews of current safety protocols, significantly reduce the risk of future incidents at Calumet in Karns City, PA.

Calumet Karns City Refining, LLC has prepared this report to offer the public insights into our operations at this facility. We have confidence that the numerous safety measures we have implemented, coupled with our commitment to continuous improvement, make it highly unlikely for any incident to impact our employees or the surrounding area.

This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for Calumet Refining facility at Karns City, Pennsylvania. 

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
Calumet is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that encompasses design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training. Robust engineering controls are in place to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. The Karns City facility is a responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Response Plan.

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
Oleum is used in the white oil oleum process. The acid treatment process of white oil consists of two operating systems designed to contact white oil with fuming sulfuric acid (Oleum) and separate the acid sludge from the treated white oil or sour oil by means of a centrifugal contactor (pod) or stainless-steel agitator. This sour oil is then neutralized in one of five agitators with soda ash (sodium carbonate) or caustic (sodium hydroxide). The acid sludge is sent to storage before it is sent off-site to be regenerated into oleum for reuse. Oleum has 20% free sulfur trioxide and is the only chemical used in a process at the site, at any one time, in quantities above the RMP threshold applicability level.
